Import your data

F. Michel-Sendis

2019-01-05

Source: vignettes/user-data.Rmd
user-data.Rmd

The sendis package was created with the aim to facilitate the import of new data. In general, if you are into criticality calculations, the first thing you will want to do is to see how other people’s results compare to your calculated data. Here are the instructions to do so.

CSV template

You can import your own data provided it is in this csv template. This template is designed to be the ouput of a criticality benchmark calculation : each observation (e.g. one benchmark result per row) has 7 features or variables (in columns). This is the format that the calcs dataset follows. Below is an example of what your csv file structure should look like before it can be imported.


FULLID MODEL CODE INST LIBVER CALCVAL CALCERR
PU-MET-FAST-029-001 Simplified Model MYCODE MYLAB JEFF-3.1.1 0.99732 0.00029
HEU-SOL-THERM-004-005 Only MYCODE MYLAB ENDFB-VIII.b4 0.99011 0.00052
LEU-COMP-THERM-016-008 Only MYCODE MYLAB JENDL-4.0 0.99998 0.00080
LEU-COMP-THERM-016-009 Only MYCODE MYLAB JEFF-3.3 0.99933 0.00022
PU-SOL-THERM-020-008 Only MYCODE MYLAB ENDFB-VII.1 0.99408 0.00051
PU-MET-THERM-001-006 Only MYCODE MYLAB JENDL-4.0 1.01009 0.00039
LEU-COMP-THERM-009-021 Only MYCODE MYLAB JENDL-4.0 1.00085 0.00025
LEU-COMP-THERM-051-007 Only MYCODE MYLAB JEFF-3.3 1.00103 0.00024
LEU-COMP-THERM-060-005 Detailed Model MYCODE MYLAB JEFF-3.1.1 1.00713 0.00011
HEU-MET-FAST-058-004 Only MYCODE MYLAB ENDFB-VII.1 1.00208 0.00031
HEU-MET-FAST-007-023 Only MYCODE MYLAB JEFF-3.3 0.99844 0.00041
PU-MET-FAST-022-001 Detailed Model MYCODE MYLAB JEFF-3.3 0.99836 0.00031
HEU-SOL-THERM-002-011 Only MYCODE MYLAB JENDL-4.0 1.00583 0.00113
LEU-SOL-THERM-016-003 Only MYCODE MYLAB JEFF-3.3 1.00475 0.00022
HEU-SOL-THERM-033-022 Detailed Model MYCODE MYLAB JEFF-3.1.1 0.99129 0.00042
HEU-MET-FAST-034-001 Only MYCODE MYLAB ENDFB-VII.1 0.99697 0.00037
HEU-MET-THERM-008-001 Simplified Model MYCODE MYLAB JENDL-4.0 1.01651 0.00038
HEU-SOL-THERM-019-001 Only MYCODE MYLAB ENDFB-VII.1 0.99771 0.00049
HEU-SOL-THERM-025-016 Only MYCODE MYLAB ENDFB-VII.1 1.00850 0.00038
LEU-COMP-THERM-052-006 Only MYCODE MYLAB JENDL-4.0 0.99270 0.00036

Format and description of variables

  • FULLID : [character] ICSBEP evaluation identifier, in the format FISS-FORM-SPEC-CASE-SUBCASE;
  • MODEL : [character] model input used, when specified, otherwise leave blank;
  • CALCVAL : [numerical], calculated value of \(k_{e\!f\!f}\);
  • CALCERR : [numerical], statistical uncertainty on \(k_{e\!f\!f}\);
  • INST : [character] used to identify institute or author of calculation
  • CODE : [character] name of the code used;
  • LIBVER : [character] library used, in the format LIB-VER (e.g.: JEFF-3.3)

Note the format for the two categorical values FULLID and LIBVER is extremely important, as these columns are parsed and split at the hyphen (‘-’) into separate variables.

Importing into sendis

The function sendis::import_submissions() imports all *.csv files in the directory specified as its argument path. This function will fail with an error if your csv files are not in the csv template that is required.

#use function import_submission(path="yourfolder")
df<-import_submissions(path = "../docs/files/mycsvfiles/")

#dataframe df now contains all of your csv data in `yourfolder/` :
head(df)
#>                   FULLID MODEL     CODE  INST  LIBVER CALCVAL CALCERR
#> 1 HEU-COMP-INTER-003-001  Only CODE-6.3 TEST1 LIB-1.0 1.00638   7e-05
#> 2 HEU-COMP-INTER-003-002  Only CODE-6.3 TEST1 LIB-1.0 1.00585   8e-05
#> 3 HEU-COMP-INTER-003-003  Only CODE-6.3 TEST1 LIB-1.0 1.00552   8e-05
#> 4 HEU-COMP-INTER-003-004  Only CODE-6.3 TEST1 LIB-1.0 1.00402   8e-05
#> 5 HEU-COMP-INTER-003-005  Only CODE-6.3 TEST1 LIB-1.0 1.00574   8e-05
#> 6 HEU-COMP-INTER-003-006  Only CODE-6.3 TEST1 LIB-1.0 0.99612   8e-05

Your data is imported but not yet in the format of the sendis dataframe. You only need to call function compile_to_sendis() in order to do so :

# merge your dataframe and bind it to the sendis dataframe
mydata<-compile_to_sendis(df)

# verify import by checking the dimensions of new dataframe `mydata`: 
dim(mydata)
#> [1] 16371    24
dim(sendis)
#> [1] 13278    24

Try plotting it :

plot_ealf(mydata)

Contribute your data

Submit your calculated results to be included as part of the calcs and sendis datasets of the package
